If it were the spirit of enlightenment, it would flow freely in all directions, reaching everywhere—above to the heavens, below coiling upon the earth—nurturing the myriad things yet leaving no trace, in the space between a bow and a rise encompassing even beyond the Four Seas. How could mere brightness suffice to reveal it?"

Thus Laozi said: *"The softest under heaven gallops through the hardest."*

*Guangyao* asked *Wu You* (the Utterly Non-Existent): "You are the most formless of all—does something truly exist, or is there truly nothing?" For form arises from the formless; how could nothing give birth to things? Thus he asked whether it truly exists or truly does not. *Wu You* made no reply. *Guangyao* could not press further, so he approached to observe its appearance. Gazing intently, he saw no shape; listening, he heard no sound. He reached out but could not grasp it; he looked afar but could not perceive its limit.

*Guangyao* said: "How sublime! Who could attain this? I can achieve *having no form*, but I have not yet reached *having no nothingness*." He meant he could make form ungraspable but could not yet transcend form entirely. If one attains *having no nothingness*, how could one reach this state?

Thus Laozi said: *"The non-existent enters where there is no space; thus I know the benefit of non-action."*

Duke Bai of Wei, consumed by thoughts of rebellion, stood after court leaning on his riding crop. The butt-end, tipped with a spike, pierced his chin. Blood flowed to the ground, yet he did not notice. When the people of Zheng heard of this, they said: "If he forgets his own chin, what will he not forget?" Duke Bai’s father had been killed by Zheng, so he feared them. This shows how the spirit strays outward while thoughts scatter within, leaving the body unguarded.

Thus when the spirit’s use extends far, what it abandons is near—*near* meaning the self.

Therefore Laozi said: *"Without stepping outside, know all under heaven; without gazing through the window, see the Dao of heaven. The farther one goes, the less one knows."* This is what it means.

When the First Emperor of Qin gained the empire, he feared he could not hold it. He sent troops to the borders, built the Great Wall, repaired passes and bridges, set up barriers and outposts, prepared relay carriages, and stationed officials at the frontiers. Yet the Liu clan seized it as easily as turning a *bizhui*—a weaving tool for mats, flipped with ease.

In the past, King Wu overthrew Zhou at the Battle of Muye. He then honored the tomb of Bi Gan, marked the lane of Shang Rong, sealed the gate of Jizi (who had fled to Joseon, leaving his home empty), restored the temple of Cheng Tang, distributed grain from Juqiao, scattered coins from Lutai, smashed drums and broke zithers, unstrung bows and cut bowstrings, slept in the open to show humility, and laid aside his sword and scepter to show no enmity. Thereupon all under heaven sang his praises and rejoiced. The feudal lords came bearing tribute, and his dynasty endured for thirty-four generations.

Thus Laozi said: *"The master of closing needs no lock, yet none can open it. The master of binding needs no rope, yet none can untie it."*

Yin Xu studied charioteering for three years without success. He privately grieved, constantly pondering it even in sleep. One midnight, he dreamed he received the *qiūjià* technique from his master. *Qiūjià* is the art of skilled driving. The next day, he went to pay his respects. His master, seeing him, said: "I do not *love* the Dao enough to teach you, for I feared you could not receive it. Today I will teach you the *qiūjià*." Yin Xu turned and ran, then bowed northward, saying: "By heaven’s blessing, I already dreamed of receiving it last night!"

Thus Laozi said: *"Attain utmost emptiness, guard perfect stillness; as the myriad things arise, I observe their return."*

In the past, Sunshu Ao was appointed Chief Minister three times without elation, and dismissed three times without sorrow.

Yanling Jizi, though the people of Wu wished to make him king, refused; Xu You declined the empire when it was offered to him; Yanzi, when swearing an oath with Cui Zhu, faced death yet did not alter his demeanor—all these men possessed a far-reaching comprehension. When the spirit penetrates life and death, what thing could delude them?

In Jing there was a man named Yin Fei who obtained a precious sword from Ganque. *Gan* is pronounced like *han*. The state of Gan lay in present-day Linhuai, where the famed swords *Dong* and *Moye* were forged in the shapes of *Dong’e* and *Donghuo*. On his return journey, as he crossed the Yangtze, he reached midstream when the waves of Yanghou arose, and two jiao coiled about his boat. Jiao are a kind of dragon. Though the boat leaked two thousand five hundred *jin* of water, the jiao did not yet dominate. Yin Fei said to the boatman, "Has anyone ever survived such a situation?" The boatman replied, "I have never seen it." Thereupon Yin Fei closed his eyes in fierce resolve, rolled up his sleeves, drew his sword, and declared: "A warrior may be persuaded by the rites of benevolence and righteousness, but he cannot be coerced or robbed. These rotting flesh and decayed bones in the river—I cast aside my sword for them. What do I cherish?" He plunged into the river and stabbed the jiao, severing its head. All aboard the boat survived, the wind and waves subsided, and the King of Jing enfeoffed him with the rank of *zhigui*.

Confucius, hearing of this, said: "Ah, the noble man who discards rotting flesh, decayed bones, and his sword—was this not Yin Fei?" Thus Laozi said: *"Only he who does not treat life as something to be clung to is worthier than one who prizes life."*

The Qi man Chunyu Kun used *congruent persuasion* to advise the King of Wei, and the king debated him. Ten chariots were prepared to send him as an envoy to Jing, but he declined and departed. Others thought his *congruent persuasion* insufficient, so they employed *crosswise persuasion* instead, and his words took on that tone. *Congruent persuasion* advocates that the strategies of the feudal lords should align; *crosswise persuasion* argues that alignment is flawed and a different approach is needed. The King of Wei halted his mission and distanced himself from him. Losing the intent of *congruence* yet failing to achieve *crosswise* success—this was the root of his failure. Words must have a foundation, affairs must have a root. Lose their foundation and root, and no matter how many skills one possesses, they are not as good as few. Thus the Zhou tripods bore the image of Chui, whose fingers were depicted as severed, to show that even the greatest craftsmanship has its limits.

Master Shen said: "A carpenter knows how to make a door and can use it, yet this does not mean he *understands* the door—for he does not grasp its essential nature. Only when the door is shut can one truly *use* it. The essence of the door lies outside the door." There was a Mohist named Tian Jiu who wished to see King Hui of Qin. He prepared his carriage and bound its shafts, but after a full year in Qin, he still could not obtain an audience. A retainer mentioned him to the King of Chu, so he went to see the king. The King of Chu was greatly pleased with him, gave him credentials, and sent him as an envoy to Qin. Upon arrival, he presented the credentials meant for the general, and King Hui of Qin was delighted with him. After leaving the audience, he sighed deeply and said to his attendants: "I remained in Qin for three years without gaining an audience. I did not realize the Dao could be reached by way of Chu." Some things are near yet seem far, while others are distant yet feel close.

Thus the conduct of the great man is not constrained by rigid rules—he simply reaches his ultimate destination. This is what is meant by the saying: "The owl tries to fly while still tethered to the string." It means that a scholar’s rise and fall are unpredictable, his advancement and retreat without constancy, and thus he cannot be bound by rules. This is like an owl tied to a string below—if it tries to soar, it cannot. The Feng River is a thousand *ren* deep and does not admit dust or filth; yet if one casts gold, iron, or a needle into it, their forms appear on the surface. It is not that the water is not deep and clear, but that fish, turtles, dragons, and serpents refuse to dwell there. Therefore, no five grains grow on bare rock, and no elk or deer roam barren mountains—there is no shelter or concealment for them.

Long ago, Zhao Wenzi asked Shu Xiang: "Among the six generals of Jin, which will perish first?" The six generals were Han, Wei, Zhao, Fan, Zhonghang, and Zhibo. Shu Xiang replied: "Zhonghang and Zhibo." Wenzi asked: "Why?" Shu Xiang answered: "In their governance, they take harshness for discernment, severity for clarity, cruelty to subordinates for loyalty, and numerous schemes for merit. It is like stretching leather: the more it is stretched, the larger it becomes, but this is the way to tear it." Thus Laozi said: *"When governance is dull and unrefined, the people are honest and simple; when governance is sharp and exacting, the people are lacking and flawed."*

Duke Jing said to the Grand Diviner: "What can your Dao do?" The diviner replied: "It can shake the earth." *Dong* means "to shake." Yanzi went to see the duke, who said: "I asked the Grand Diviner what his Dao could do, and he said it could shake the earth. Can the earth truly be shaken?" Yanzi remained silent and did not answer. After leaving, he met the Grand Diviner and said: "Once I saw a *gou* star between Fang and Xin—will the earth shake?" The *gou* star is a guest star. *Si* refers to Fang. When the *gou* star lingers between Fang and Xin, the earth trembles. The Grand Diviner said: "Yes." Yanzi departed, and the Grand Diviner hurried to see the duke, saying: "I cannot shake the earth—the earth is about to shake on its own."

Tian Ziyang, a minister of Qi, heard of this and said: "Yanzi’s silence was to spare the Grand Diviner’s life. His visit to the Grand Diviner was to prevent the duke from being deceived. Yanzi can be called loyal to his superior and kind to his subordinate." Thus Laozi said: *"Square yet not cutting, sharp yet not wounding."*

Duke Wen of Wei feasted with his ministers at Quyang. As the wine flowed freely, the duke sighed deeply and said: "I alone have no Yu Rang as my minister." Yu Rang served Zhibo and died for him in his time of trouble, so Duke Wen longed to have him as a retainer. Jian Zhong raised a goblet and offered it, saying: "Let me penalize you, my lord." *Fu* means "to penalize," referring to punishing the lord with wine.

The lord said, "Why?" He replied, "I have heard that parents with a destined fate do not recognize a filial son, and a lord with the Dao does not recognize a loyal minister. What kind of lord was Yu Rang’s master? Yu Rang served his lord, yet his lord was killed—what was he like? He is not worthy of esteem."

Duke Wen received the goblet, drained it, and did not offer it in return. *Jiao* means "to drain." He said, "Had I ministers like Guan Zhong and Bao Shu, I would have had the merit of Yu Rang." Thus Laozi said: *"When the state is benighted and in chaos, there are loyal ministers."*

Confucius observed the temple of Duke Huan (lord of Lu) and saw a vessel there called a *youzhi*. *You* means "placed to the right." Confucius said, "Excellent! How fortunate I am to see this vessel." He turned and said, "Disciples, bring water." When water was brought and poured into it, the vessel stood upright when half-full—*half-full* meaning the water reached the vessel’s midpoint. When filled to the brim, it overturned. Confucius’s expression suddenly changed, and he said, "Excellent! This is how one maintains fullness."

Zigong, standing beside him, asked, "May I inquire how to maintain fullness?" Confucius said, "By yielding and diminishing it." Zigong asked, "What does it mean to yield and diminish it?" Confucius replied, "All things flourish and then decline; joy reaches its peak and turns to sorrow. The sun moves on from its zenith, and the moon wanes after it is full. Thus, the wise and perceptive guard themselves with foolishness; the learned and eloquent guard themselves with restraint; the martial and resolute guard themselves with awe; the wealthy and exalted guard themselves with humility; those whose virtue extends to all under heaven guard themselves with deference. These five principles are how the former kings preserved the realm without losing it. To reverse these five is to invite peril." Thus Laozi said: *"Those who preserve this Dao do not seek fullness. Only by not being full can one remain whole without becoming new."*

King Wu asked Taigong, "I have conquered Zhou and taken the realm—this is a minister killing his lord and a subject overthrowing his superior. I fear that later generations will never cease using arms and endlessly contend. What can be done?" Taigong said, "Excellent is Your Majesty’s question. Before capturing game, hunters fear only that their wounds are too slight, and when hunting birds, they fear the prey might escape unharmed—thus they fear wounds that are too small. Once captured, they fear only that too much flesh is damaged. If you wish to hold it long, then stop up the people’s senses—*senses* meaning ears, eyes, nose, and mouth. Laozi said: *'Stop up their senses.'* Let the Dao be complete in useless affairs and vexatious teachings. Let them all delight in their occupations and fulfill their desires, so that the bright and the Way become obscure. Then remove their madness and bind it to wood—*madness* meaning disheveled hair, and *waterfowl* referring to a bird’s crest. Those who know refinement wear the crest. Remove their swords and gird them with tablets. Enforce three years of mourning to prevent the proliferation of kin. Elevate polite speech and humble deference to make the people non-contentious. Use wine and meat to connect them, lutes and zithers to entertain them, and ghosts and spirits to awe them. Multiply rituals and elaborate ceremonies to obscure their essence. Encourage lavish burials and prolonged mourning to exhaust their resources. Let them place pearls in the mouth and adorn the corpse with silken cords to impoverish their wealth. Dig deep tombs and raise high mounds to exhaust their strength. When families are poor and clans diminished, those who worry about calamity will be impoverished. By transforming customs in this way, you can hold the realm without losing it." Thus Laozi said: *"When transformation stirs and desires arise, I will suppress them with the nameless uncarved block."*

*The Eighteenth Scroll of the Huainanzi’s Explanations concludes here.*

**Comprehensive Discourse on Instruction, Part One**

This discourse broadly examines the successes and failures of past and present, using the Dao as the means of transformation, ultimately returning to unity—hence the title "Comprehensive Discourse," from which the chapter takes its name.

In ancient times, there were those who ruled all under Heaven wearing helmets and fur garments with turned collars. These were the ages before the Three Sovereigns. *Mou* refers to the helmet worn on the head, indicating that caps had not yet been invented. *Quanling* describes fur clothing with the hide folded and stitched, like the reversed collars of the northern tribes’ leather robes. Another interpretation holds that *mou* means unbound hair, and *quan* means merely wrapping the neck—both without adornment. Virtue arose without shame, and penal models were unused. They bestowed without seizing, for *bestow* meant providing the people with wealth, and *not seizing* meant making no demands upon them. All under Heaven did not criticize their attire but shared in their virtue. *Criticize* here means to reproach, and *shared* means to return to. In that era, yin and yang were harmonious, wind and rain timely, the myriad things flourished, governance was not oppressive, and lives were not cut short. The nests of crows and magpies could be reached and examined by bending down, and birds and beasts could be led by halters—why then were wide robes, broad sashes, curved collars, and ceremonial caps necessary? *Wide robes* refer to square-cut garments, like the left-side robes of officials today. *Broad sashes* are large belts, as in the *Book of Songs*: "hanging sashes like trailing stones." *Curved collars* are today’s garments with turned-back sleeves. *Wei* is the *weimao* cap, and *zhangfu* is another name for a cap.

In ancient times, people dwelled in marshes and double caves. *Dwelled* means to reside, and *double caves* are layered burrows. Another interpretation holds that caves were dug into embankments and cliffs to serve as dwellings. In winter, they could not withstand frost and snow; in summer, they could not endure the heat, stifling air, and biting insects. As the *Book of Songs* says: "The insects come..." The sages then arose—*arose* means to initiate—and built earthen walls and framed timber to construct palaces. *Framed* means to join, referring to the interlocking of beams. With ridgepoles above and eaves below, they sheltered from wind and rain. *Ridgepoles* are the roof’s main beams, and *eaves* are the overhanging edges. Thus they avoided cold and heat, and the people found contentment. *Contentment* means joy.

When Boyi first created clothing—Boyi was a minister of the Yellow Emperor. The *Genealogical Records* states that Boyi made robes and skirts. Another account holds that Boyi was the Yellow Emperor—he twisted hemp fibers into threads, weaving them by hand, the result resembling a net. *Tan* means sharp, and *suo* means labor. *Tan* is read as *tranquil*, unmoving. Later generations invented the loom and shuttle to improve its use, allowing people to cover their bodies and ward off cold. *Cover* means to conceal, and *ward off* means to resist.

In ancient times, people plowed with sharpened plowshares and hoed with ground conch shells. *Sharpened* means to make keen, and *plowshares* are spade-like tools. *Conch* refers to large clams, which were ground to a sharp edge for use. *Hoeing* means clearing weeds from seedlings. They cut firewood with hooked blades and drew water with earthen jars. *Hooked blades* are sickles, read like *juyang* in Jiyin. *Firewood* refers to kindling. *Earthen jars* are jars; in Yanzhou, small jars are called *zhen*, and in Youzhou, they are called *wa*. The people labored much but gained little. Later generations invented the plow, plowshare, mallet, and hoe, cut firewood with axes, and drew water with well-sweeps. *Mallets* are read as *you*, meaning to pound clods. In the Three Adjuncts, they are called *tai*, used to cover seeds. Thus the people found ease and greater benefit.

In ancient times, great rivers and famous valleys cut off roads, preventing travel. They then hollowed logs and joined planks to make boats and ferries. *Hollowed* means to make empty, and *joined* means to connect. Boats linked together formed ferries. Thus, regions with and without resources could exchange goods. *Exchange* means to transport what one has to where it is lacking. They then made soft shoes to traverse a thousand *li*, sparing the toil of carrying loads on their shoulders. *Soft shoes* are light footwear. *Toil* means labor. Later, they invented wheeled carts and erected carriages, harnessing horses and yoking oxen, allowing people to reach distant places without fatigue, for they no longer bore loads on their shoulders.

When fierce birds and savage beasts harmed people and there was no means to defend against them, they smelted metal and forged iron to make weapons and blades, so that savage beasts could no longer cause harm. With weapons and blades prepared, they could not harm people. Thus, when people faced difficulties, they sought convenience; when afflicted by misfortune, they devised defenses. Each person used their knowledge to avoid harm and pursue benefit. Established customs could not be followed blindly, and tools and implements could not remain unchanged. *Follow* means to adhere. What could be altered at the time was altered, hence it is said they could not be. Thus, the laws and measures of former kings underwent changes.

In ancient marriage rites, the groom was not addressed as the host, for the betrothed himself was not called by name but referred to by his father, elder brothers, teachers, or friends. Shun did not inform his parents before marrying, which was contrary to ritual. Yao, knowing Shun’s worth, gave him his two daughters in marriage, but Shun did not inform his father, who was obstinate and often sought to kill him. Shun knew that if he informed his father, he would not be allowed to marry. There is no greater unfiliality than having no descendants, so Mencius said, "Shun’s not informing was as good as informing." The eldest son was to be established as heir, but King Wen set aside Boyi Kao and appointed King Wu instead, which was not in accordance with the system.

The rites prescribe marriage at thirty, for when yin and yang had not yet separated, both were born from *zi*. Counting from *zi*, men move leftward thirty years to reach *si*, and women move rightward twenty years to also reach *si*, where husband and wife unite. Thus the sages, following this principle, established the ritual that men marry at thirty and women at twenty. *For* men, counting from *si* leftward ten years reaches *yin*, so people are born in the tenth month at *yin*, hence men’s counting begins from *yin*. For women, counting from *si* rightward reaches *shen*, so they are also born in the tenth month at *shen*, hence women’s counting begins from *shen*.

**The Nineteenth Scroll of the Huainanzi’s Explanations**
**Recorded by Xu Shen, Grandee Secretary and Libationer**

Beribkao, elder brother of King Wu, was passed over when the worthy was enthroned and the younger replaced the elder—this was but the sages’ expedient measure. King Wen fathered King Wu at fifteen, which was not the proper rule. The Year Star completes its circuit in twelve years, and the celestial Dao is perfected in twelve, so the lord of a state is capped at twelve and then marries. To father a child at fifteen is to emphasize the succession of the state, not to follow the old statutes. From the preceding passage, it should have been Beribkao who married.

The Xia dynasty laid the deceased on the eastern steps for the funeral rites. According to ritual, the offering of rice was made beneath the window, the minor encoffining within the door, and the major encoffining on the eastern steps. When on the bier, the deceased is called a *shi*; when in the coffin, a *jiu*. To lay the deceased in the position of the guest and to perform the ancestral rites in the courtyard before burial in the tomb—yet on the eastern steps, the deceased still occupies the position of the host, and one cannot bear to distance them as a guest. The Yin people laid the deceased between the two pillars, for *ying* are pillars. The Record states: “The Yin laid the deceased in the hall between the two pillars, where host and guest share the space.” The Zhou people laid the deceased on the western steps, thereby sending them off as a guest. Such are the differences in these rites.

The Youyu clan used earthen coffins, for the Youyu were the age of Shun. Earthen coffins were made of fired clay. The Xia dynasty, being sagely and encompassing, refers to the age of Yu. With no inner or outer coffin, they used earthen tiles two feet wide and four feet long, stacking them on their sides to shield the body from the soil—this was called *sagely encompassing*. The Yin people used an outer coffin, fashioning it from cypress wood of appropriate thickness, with the inner coffin as the standard. The Zhou people placed screens along the walls, these being differences in burial practices. The Zhou used both inner and outer coffins, so they set up screens along the walls, shaped like today’s waist-high fans, painted with patterns and inserted into the sides of the hearse as ornamentation. The number and size varied according to the rank and mandate of the deceased.

The Xia dynasty sacrificed in darkness, within the chamber, at midnight. The Yin people sacrificed in the light, in the hall, at dawn. The Zhou people sacrificed at sunrise, in the courtyard. *Zhao* means the courtyard. Such are the differences in sacrificial rites.

Yao had the *Great Eulogy*, Yao’s music. Shun had the *Nine Shao*, Shun’s music. The Book states: “The *Xiao Shao* in nine movements.” Yu had the *Great Xia*, Yu’s music. Tang had the *Great Hu*, Tang’s music. King Wu of Zhou had the *Martial Elegy*, King Wu’s music. Such are the differences in music.

Thus the Five Emperors followed different Ways yet their virtue covered the world, and the Three Kings pursued distinct affairs yet their names endured for later generations—all adapted to the times and established rites and music. It is like the Master Kuang adjusting the bridges of his zither: though the shifts up and down follow no fixed inch or foot, none fail to strike the right note. Therefore, one who understands the essence of rites and music can create music, for they have a fundamental principle within and thus know the compass and square’s full reach. *Ju* means square; *yue* means the standard of measure.

Duke Zhao of Lu had a compassionate mother whom he loved, and when she died, he wore a white hempen cap for her, hence the mourning rites for a compassionate mother. A compassionate mother is one whom the father commands to raise oneself. Compared to the concubine of a grandee or the wife of a knight, she is called a *female mother*, and the ritual prescribes three months of hempen mourning. Duke Zhao alone wore the white hempen cap, illustrating the origin of this recorded ritual.

The Marquis of Yang killed the Marquis of Liao and took his wife, so the grand banquet abandoned the rites for the lady. The *Marquis of Yang* was the lord of Yangling. The *Marquis of Liao* was a descendant of Gaoyao, lord of a state of the Yan clan, now in Lujiang. In ancient times, during the grand banquet, the lord held the goblet while the lady held the bean. The Marquis of Yang, seeing the beauty of the Marquis of Liao’s wife, killed the marquis and married her, thereby abolishing the rites for presenting the lady. This is the origin of the recorded abolition.

The former kings’ institutions were abandoned when they became unsuitable.

In the degenerate age, good deeds are recorded; thus, rites and music have never been immutable. Therefore, the sage establishes rites and music but is not bound by them. The sage can create rites and music yet is not constrained by rites and music. Governing a state has its constants, but benefiting the people is the foundation. *Foundation* means the essential. Government and education have their norms, but effective commands are paramount. *Norms* means constants; *paramount* means the highest. If it benefits the people, there is no need to imitate antiquity. If it suffices for the matter at hand, there is no need to follow old ways. *Old* means customary. As the tradition states, "The old is not necessarily good," for old ways may also bring fault.

When the Xia and Shang declined, they perished by refusing to change their laws. *Perished* refers to Jie and Zhou. When the Three Dynasties arose, they did not follow one another yet reigned as kings. The *Three Dynasties* were Yu, Tang, and Wu. *Follow* means to imitate. Thus, the sage adapts laws to the times and rites to customs. *Adapts* means to change. Clothing, tools, and implements each suit their use; laws, decrees, and commands each fit their circumstances. Therefore, changing antiquity cannot be condemned, nor is following custom sufficient praise. *Following* means adhering; *custom* means the usual.

The hundred rivers, though their sources differ, all flow into the sea, taking the sea as their master. The hundred schools, though their pursuits vary, all strive for order. *Pursuits* means affairs, and *order* is the essential. When the kingly Way declined, the *Odes* arose—the *Odes* serve to criticize the kingly Way. When the Zhou house abandoned rites and virtue collapsed, the *Spring and Autumn* emerged—the *Spring and Autumn* serves to sever what does not follow rites and virtue. The *Odes* and *Spring and Autumn* are the finest of learning, yet both arose in declining ages. Confucians follow them to teach and guide the world, but how can this compare to the flourishing Three Dynasties? To value the *Odes* and *Spring and Autumn* as the ancient Way, or to esteem the times before their composition, is to mistake a broken Way for its wholeness. Reciting the *Odes* and *Documents* of the former kings is not as good as hearing their words; hearing their words is not as good as grasping their intent. To grasp the intent behind the sage’s words is to attain what words cannot express. The sage’s words are subtle and profound; though ordinary people may grasp them, their mouths cannot articulate them. Thus, "The Dao that can be spoken is not the constant Dao." The *constant Dao* is deep, hidden, and obscure—unutterable, like the sage’s words, which are too subtle to be spoken.

When the Duke of Zhou served King Wen, he acted without arbitrary authority. *Arbitrary authority* means unilateral decision-making. He never acted on his own initiative but sought permission before proceeding. His person seemed too frail to bear his robes; his words seemed too hesitant to leave his mouth. He served King Wen with reverence, yielding and compliant, as if unable to bear the responsibility, fearing to fail him. *Yielding and compliant* describes his gentle deference. *Unable to bear* and *fearing to fail* show his utmost caution. *Yielding* is read like *tong* in *tingtong*; *compliant* is read like the second character in *li□*. He could be called a filial son.

When King Wu died and King Cheng was young, the Duke of Zhou succeeded King Wen’s enterprise, assumed the throne’s authority, and administered the realm’s governance. *Authority* refers to the throne’s records; *governance* means administration. *Authority* may also be written as *steps*. He pacified the barbarian rebellions—*pacified* means to quell the Yi and Di who disrupted the Xia—and punished the crimes of Guan and Cai. The Viscount of Cai was the Duke of Zhou’s elder brother; the Viscount of Guan was his younger brother. The two brothers supervised Yin but incited Wu Geng’s slander to sow chaos in Zhou. The Duke of Zhou executed them for the state’s sake. As the tradition states, "Great righteousness overrides kinship."

He bore the screen and received the feudal lords in audience. *Bore* means to lean against; *screen* refers to the space between the door and window, signifying the south-facing position. He meted out punishments and rewards, made decisions without hesitation, and resolved matters in his heart. His might shook heaven and earth; his voice awed the realm. *Awed* means to subdue, to bring the Four Seas into submission. He could be called martial.

When King Cheng came of age, the Duke of Zhou returned the throne’s records and governance, facing north to offer tribute and serve as a minister. *Returned* means to restore; he presented the jade and silk of tribute, observing the rites of a minister. He sought permission before acting and reported before proceeding, consulting on every matter. *Reported* means to inform. He harbored no willful ambitions, displayed no pride in his achievements, and showed no arrogance in his virtue. He neither boasted of his merits nor exalted his goodness. He could be called a dutiful minister.

Thus, one man’s life encompassed three transformations to respond to the times. How much more so when rulers change with each generation and states change lords with each succession? People use their positions to indulge their likes and dislikes—each employs their favor and rank to pursue what they love and hate, wielding their power to satisfy their desires. To expect a single rite or fixed law to meet the demands of changing circumstances is clearly impossible. *A single rite* is not an adaptable rite; *a fixed law* is not an adaptable law. Thus, it is said they cannot *hit the mark of expediency*. *Expediency* means adapting to circumstances without losing the mean.

Therefore, what the sage follows is called the Dao; what the sage does is called affairs. The Dao is like metal and stone—once tuned, it does not change. Affairs are like the zither and lute—each string requires a new tuning. *Metal and stone* refer to bells, which, once tuned, do not alter. The *zither and lute* have strings of varying tension and movable bridges, so their tuning adapts to each affair.

Thus, laws, institutions, rites, and virtue are tools for governing people, not the essence of governance. Laws, institutions, rites, and virtue can serve as the foundation of governance, but governance itself lies in the ruler’s virtue. They are like the bow and arrow, tools for shooting, yet hitting the mark depends on the archer’s skill. Therefore, benevolence is the warp, and righteousness the weft—these are unchanging for ten thousand generations. As for assessing one’s abilities and examining their use in the times, even daily changes may be fitting.

One must assess one’s own abilities, examine one’s conduct in due time, select what is good and esteem its use—there is no need to follow convention. Thus it is said: even daily changes may be fitting. Only benevolence and righteousness cannot be altered, and so they remain unchanged for ten thousand generations.

Is there any fixed law under heaven? One must adapt to the times and act as is fitting. When governance aligns with the affairs of the age, accords with human principles, follows the patterns of Heaven and Earth, and harmonizes with the spirits, then proper order may be established. *Aligns* means to accord; *harmonizes* means to follow.

In ancient times, people were sincere and craftsmen steadfast. Merchants were honest, and women chaste. *Sincere* means honest and unpretentious; *steadfast* means firm in qi and meticulous. *Honest* means free from deceit; *chaste* means upright and without impropriety. Thus, governance and education were easily transformed, and customs readily shifted.

In the present age, virtue has further declined, and the people’s customs have grown ever more shallow. To govern a people already corrupted with the laws of simplicity and gravity is like driving a wild horse without bit, bridle, whip, or goad. *Bit* refers to the iron piece placed in the horse’s mouth, as large as the yolk of a chicken’s egg, by which the horse is controlled. *Bridle* is the headstall and reins. *Wild horse* means a rearing, unruly horse.

In the past, Shennong ruled without decrees, and the people followed; without decrees, governance relied on knotted cords. Tang and Yu had decrees but no punishments; their decrees were resplendent with culture and refinement. Their governance was ever rooted in benevolence and righteousness, so the people did not violate laws or incur execution—thus it is said there were no punishments. The Xia lords did not break their word, for their speech was trustworthy. The Yin people swore oaths, binding themselves with words, and did not violate them. The Zhou people made covenants, gathering when matters arose and swearing oaths when discord emerged. *Covenants* involved slaughtering animals and drinking their blood as a pledge.

Yet in the present age—referring to when the Prince of Huainan composed this work—people are cruel in inquiry and quick to shame, greedy for gain and lacking in shame. To govern them with the Way of Shennong would surely lead to chaos. Bocheng Zigao resigned his rank as feudal lord to till the fields, and the world held him in high esteem. Bocheng Zigao was likely a man of Yao’s time. *Inquiry* is read as the descendants of the Xia lords. Today, those who resign office to live in seclusion rank among the lowest of their villages—how can they be compared?

In ancient warfare, only bows and swords were used; wooden spears had no striking edge, and long halberds no piercing tip. *Wooden spears* were made of wood; *no striking edge* means they lacked an iron blade. *Piercing tip* refers to the point. *Wooden* is read like the second character in *qicao* (grub). In later ages, siege towers were used for attack, and mobile shields for defense. *Siege towers* were tall structures used to overlook enemy cities and breach their walls. *Mobile shields* were gradually advanced; one account calls them a type of armor, as in the *Guoyu*: "presenting armor of patterned weave." *Shields* were canopies to block arrows. Repeating crossbows were used for shooting, and armored chariots for combat. *Repeating crossbows* had a single string drawn by oxen, with blades mounted on either side and triggered by a mechanism—called *armored chariots*. *Armored* is read like the second character in *gengxiao* (a type of rope).

In ancient times, when attacking a state, one did not kill the young or capture the gray-haired. *Young* refers to children; *gray-haired* means those with white hair. What was once deemed righteous is now mocked. What the ancients considered honorable—like Bocheng Zigao—is now seen as shameful, ranking among the lowest of one’s village. What the ancients used to establish order is now the cause of chaos.

Shennong and Fuxi did not employ rewards or punishments, yet the people did no wrong. Yet those who establish governance cannot abandon laws to rule the people, for they cannot match Shennong and Fuxi. Shun subdued the Youmiao with shield and battle-axe; at first, the Youmiao rebelled, but when Shun danced with shield and axe between the two staircases, they submitted. This was the power of virtue to transform and draw them near. Yet those who wage war cannot lay down their armor and weapons to restrain the violent, for they cannot match Shun.

From this, we see that laws and institutions serve to evaluate customs and regulate urgency or leniency, while tools and weapons adapt to the times and suit the occasion. The sage creates laws, and all things follow them—*follow* means to comply. The worthy establish rites, and the unworthy are constrained by them—*constrained* means to be checked. Those bound by laws cannot be entrusted with grand undertakings; those confined by rites cannot be made to respond to change. One who does not distinguish between clear and muddy tones cannot be tasked with tuning instruments; one who does not understand the roots of order and chaos cannot be tasked with creating laws. Only those with uniquely perceptive ears and uniquely discerning vision can then master the Way and act accordingly.

The Yin altered the Xia, the Zhou altered the Yin, and the Spring and Autumn period altered the Zhou—*altered* means to change. The rites of the Three Dynasties differed; which antiquity should one follow? When great men act, their disciples follow—*follow* means to comply. One who understands the origins of law and governance adapts to the times; one who does not know their source, though they follow the ancients, will ultimately bring chaos.

The laws and records of the present age change with the times; rites and righteousness shift with customs. Yet scholars cling to the past, inheriting old teachings and adhering to outdated texts, believing that nothing but these can bring order. This is like trying to fit a square peg into a round hole—seeking a proper and secure fit will be difficult indeed.

Today, the Confucians and Mohists praise the Three Dynasties and Kings Wen and Wu but do not practice their ways. This is to speak of what they do not do; unable to act, they merely speak. They do not adapt to the present age, instead practicing what they oppose. Praising what they approve while practicing what they disapprove, they exhaust their days in deep thought yet contribute nothing to governance, wearing out their bodies and depleting their wisdom to no benefit for their lord.

Now, why do painters prefer to depict ghosts and demons yet dislike painting dogs and horses? It is because ghosts and demons do not appear in the world, while dogs and horses are seen every day. To preserve stability and govern chaos, wisdom is essential; to first invoke the ancients while discussing the Way—even fools can do that in excess.

Thus, laws that are not applied, the sage-kings do not practice; words that are unverified, the sage-kings do not heed. *Heed* means to accept.

The qi of Heaven and Earth is nothing greater than harmony. Through harmony, the myriad things are born. Harmony means yin and yang are balanced, day and night are distinct, and living things emerge. At the spring equinox, they are born; at the autumn equinox, they mature. Birth and maturation must attain the essence of harmony. *Essence* refers to qi.

Therefore, the Way of the sage is tolerant yet exacting, stern yet warm, gentle yet upright, fierce yet benevolent. This speaks of the mutual complement of hardness and softness, tolerance and severity. Too hard, it snaps; too soft, it bends. The sage stands precisely between hardness and softness, thereby grasping the root of the Way. *Root* means source.

Accumulated yin sinks; accumulated yang soars. Only when yin and yang interact can harmony be achieved.

The carpenter’s line serves as a measure: it can be coiled and extended. Pulled taut, it becomes straight and clear. *Clear* means visible. Thus, the sage embodies it. *Embodies* means practices.

That which is long yet not overbearing, short yet not insufficient, straight yet not rigid, enduring yet not forgotten—only the carpenter’s line achieves this.

Thus, if benevolence is overindulged, it becomes weakness, and weakness lacks authority. *Overindulged* means misapplied. If severity is overindulged, it becomes cruelty, and cruelty lacks harmony. If affection is overindulged, it becomes indulgence, and indulgence lacks command. *Indulgence* means laxity. If punishment is overindulged, it becomes tyranny, and tyranny loses kinship. *Tyranny* means harm. One who harms others will find no one close to them.

In the past, Duke Jian of Qi relinquished the reins of his state and entrusted them entirely to his chief minister. *Duke Jian* was the son of Duke Dao and Yangsheng. *Chief minister* refers to Chen Chengzi. The generals and ministers usurped power and monopolized authority, forming private factions, so that the public Way was not practiced. *Factions* means cliques. Thus, Chen Cheng, Tian Chang, and Chi Yi Zi Pi succeeded in their rebellion. *Rebellion* refers to the assassination of Duke Jian. This caused the House of Lü to be cut off from its ancestral sacrifices. *The House of Lü* was the lineage of the Grand Duke; Duke Jian was its descendant. *Cut off from ancestral sacrifices* means the Chen clan replaced them. The state came to be ruled by the Chen clan—this arose from excessive softness and weakness.

Zi Yang of Zheng was resolute and fond of punishment. *Zi Yang* was the lord of Zheng; some say he was the prime minister. In meting out punishments, he was unyielding and unforgiving. When a retainer broke a bow, fearing punishment and execution, he took advantage of the chaos caused by a mad dog to kill Zi Yang. *Retainer* means a household minister. The people of the state pursued the mad dog in uproar, and the retainer used the opportunity to kill Zi Yang, fearing his severity. This was the consequence of excessive hardness and severity.

Now, those who do not understand the Way see the weak and yielding being encroached upon and thus pride themselves on being resolute and firm. When they see the resolute and firm perish, they pride themselves on being weak and yielding. This stems from having no inner principle, while their perceptions and experiences are contradictory and erratic. *Contradictory* means conflicting. Thus, they pass their lives without a fixed direction. *Fixed* means settled; *direction* means destination.

It is like one who does not understand music attempting to sing: if the notes are muddied, they become stifled and lack modulation. *Stifled* means obstructed; *modulation* refers to the *zhuan* in *chuan* (transmission). If the notes are too clear, they become shrill and unmelodic. *Shrill* means withered; *melodic* means harmonious. But when Han E, Qin Qing, and Xue Tan sing, *All three were skilled singers.* or when Hou Tong and Man Sheng perform, *Both were skilled singers; some say Man Sheng means "long notes."* their hearts are stirred, their feelings accumulate within, and when their voices pour forth, none fail to align with the pitch-pipes and resonate with the human heart.

Why is this? Because within, they have a fundamental principle to determine clarity and turbidity, not relying on external influences but serving as their own standard.

Now, consider the blind walking on the road: if someone says "left," they go left; if someone says "right," they go right. If they encounter a gentleman, they may easily find the way, but if they meet a petty person, they fall into a ditch. Why? Because their eyes cannot perceive things. *Perceive* means to engage with.

Thus, when Wei employed both Lou Diao and Wu Qi, it lost the Western River. *Duke Wen of Wei appointed Lou Diao and Wu Qi but ignored other worthies. Qin attacked and seized the land of Western River.* When King Min exclusively relied on Tan Chu, he died in the eastern temple. *Min* is read like the *Wen* in *Wenshui*. *King Min* was a descendant of Tian Chang and succeeded the House of Lü as marquis of Qi. After the Spring and Autumn period, he usurped the title of king. *Tan Chu* was a general of Chu who fled to Qi and became a minister. King Min was unprincipled, and Tan Chu killed him, suspending his sinews from the beam of the temple gate, where he died after three days. See the *Strategies of the Warring States.* This was due to lacking the art of governance.

King Wen employed both Lü Wang and Duke Shao Shi and became king. *Lü Wang* was Grand Duke Lü Shang, skilled in military strategy. *Shi* was Duke Shao Kang, skilled in governing the people and celebrated in the *Ode to the Sweet Pear.* King Zhuang of Chu exclusively relied on Sunshu Ao and became hegemon. This was due to possessing the art of governance. *Sunshu Ao* was a grandee of Chu who recommended Jia Bo Ying’s son. Some say he was a youth, but his worth was recognized, thus achieving hegemony.*

Music is made with strings and songs, drums and dances; propriety is cultivated with circling and bowing. Elaborate burials and prolonged mourning are observed to send off the dead—these were established by Confucius, yet Mozi criticized them. *Criticized* means reproached. Universal love, exalting the worthy, revering ghosts, and rejecting fate—these were established by Mozi, yet Yangzi criticized them. *Universal love* is shown by honoring the Three Elders and Five More; *exalting the worthy* is practiced through selecting scholars and the great archery ceremony; *revering ghosts* is done by solemnly sacrificing to the father; *rejecting fate* is achieved by following the four seasons. All these were not valued by Yangzi, hence his criticism.

Preserving one’s nature and safeguarding authenticity, not allowing things to burden the body—these were established by Yangzi, yet Mencius criticized them. *Preserving one’s nature and safeguarding authenticity* refers to not plucking a single hair to benefit the world, refusing to let things burden one’s body. Mencius studied under the disciples of Zisi, perfected the virtues of Tang, Yu, and the Three Dynasties, expounded the *Odes* and *Documents*, and conveyed the intent of Confucius. He opposed the excessive words of Yang and Mo, hence his criticism.

People’s choices and rejections differ, each possessing their own enlightened understanding. Thus, right and wrong have their proper places—when one attains the proper place, there is no wrong; when one loses it, there is no right. The peoples of Danxue, Taimeng, Fanzhong, Kongtong, Daxia, Beihu, Qigong, and Xiugu—each holds different views on right and wrong, their customs clashing in opposition. Danxue lies in the south, beneath the sun’s descent; Taimeng is in the west, where the sun sets. Fanzhong is a kingdom whose people walk southward yet leave footprints facing north. Kongtong is a land beneath the loftiest peaks; Daxia lies in the west. Beihu is in the south; the peoples of Qigong and Xiugu dwell in the southwest. All eight of these lie beyond the Nine Provinces, within the domain of the Eight Yi.

Rulers and ministers, superiors and inferiors, husbands and wives, fathers and sons—each has means by which they employ one another. What is right here is not right there; what is wrong here is not wrong there. "Here" serves as a near analogy for the Hua peoples; "there," a distant analogy for the Eight Yi. To discard what the Hua peoples deem right because the Eight Yi deem it wrong, or to practice what the Hua peoples deem wrong because the Eight Yi deem it right, is like the axe, adze, mallet, and chisel—each has its proper application. *Application* means suitability.

In the time of Yu, governance was conducted through the five tones. Yu, the fifth-generation descendant of Zhuanxu and son of Gun, was named Wenming. Upon receiving the abdication and achieving success, he was called Yu. The five tones—gong, shang, jue, zhi, and yu—were employed thus: bells, drums, chimes, and bells with clappers were hung, and small drums set out to await scholars from the four directions. A proclamation was issued: "Those who instruct me in the Dao shall strike the drum"—for the Dao harmonizes yin and yang, and striking the drum once adjusts the five tones. "Those who discuss affairs with me shall shake the bell"—the bell, a metal mouth with a wooden tongue, produces sound; since affairs are not of one kind, it is shaken. "Those who speak to me of concerns shall strike the chime"—the chime is made of stone, its sound urgent; concerns, too, are urgent matters, hence the chime is struck. "Those with legal disputes shall shake the small drum"—disputes involve litigation, and litigation is a single matter, hence the small drum is used.

At that time, Yu rose ten times for every meal and grasped his hair thrice while washing—*a meal* refers to food. He wearied himself for the people of the world, *wearied* meaning toil, as in the phrase "toil and welcome." If, in such times, one could not attain goodness or demonstrate loyalty, it was due to insufficient talent. At that time, if one could not attain goodness or offer loyalty, it was because one lacked the capacity.

In the time of Qin, lofty towers and grand gardens were constructed, distant thoroughfares laid, and metal statues cast. In the twenty-sixth year of the First Emperor of Qin, having just unified the realm, a giant appeared in Lintao, standing five *zhang* tall with footprints six *chi* long. Modeling its form, he cast metal statues to resemble it—these were the figures known as Wengzhong and Junhe. Conscripts were sent to garrison the frontiers, and taxes of hay and straw were levied to supply the state’s needs. Poll taxes were collected by headcount, and levies were gathered like dust in a dustpan, all delivered to the *Shaofu*. *Poll taxes* were assessed per capita; *dustpan levies* resembled dustpans in their sweeping collection of wealth. The *Shaofu* was an official position, akin to the later *Sinong*.

Strong men were dispatched west to Lintao and Didao—Lintao was a county in Longxi where the Tao River rises in the north; Didao was a county in Hanyang. They were sent east to Kuaiji, Fushi, and beyond—Kuaiji was a mountain, and Fushi rose and fell with the water, never submerged. All these lay within the borders of Liaoxi. One account places Kuaiji Mountain beneath Mount Tai, where the First Emperor performed the feng sacrifice at Mount Tai and the shan sacrifice at Kuaiji; *Kuaiji* is sometimes written as *Canghai*. They were sent south to Yuzhang and Guilin—Yuzhang was the Yuzhang Commandery, and Guilin the Yulin Commandery. They were sent north to Feihu and Yangyuan—Feihu likely refers to Feihu Mountain south of Daijun; Yangyuan was perhaps in Taiyuan. Another account places it five *li* east of Guangchang in Daijun. Corpses filled the roads and ditches.

At that time, those who offered loyal remonstrance were called inauspicious, and those who spoke of benevolence and righteousness were deemed mad. By the time of the High Emperor, he preserved what was lost and restored what was broken. The High Emperor was Liu Bang. Upholding the great righteousness of the world, he personally rolled up his sleeves and seized weapons to plead for the people’s lives before Heaven. Wielding sharp blades, he punished the unrighteous to seek the people’s deliverance, entreating Heaven for their fate.

At that time, the land’s heroes, talents, and valiant men lay exposed in the wilds and marshes—those surpassing a thousand were called *talents*, a hundred *heroes*, and ten thousand *valiant*. They advanced beneath arrows and stones, and behind them lay ravines and gullies. Emerging from a hundred deaths to grasp a single life, they contended for the world’s power. *Lay* means to fall; *grasp* means to reach, pronounced like *dai* in *rengdai*. They roused their martial spirit and steeled their resolve to decide their fate in a single day.

At that time, those who wore flowing robes and wide sashes while discoursing on the teachings of the Ru and Mo were deemed unworthy—this spoke to the valor of the age. By the time the violent chaos was overcome—*overcome* meaning to vanquish the violent chaos—the realm was greatly pacified. The legacy of King Wen was continued, and the achievements of King Wu were established—King Wen’s legacy was the Mandate he received, and King Wu’s achievements were the punishment of the unrighteous. The maps and registers of the Son of Heaven were trodden, and the Liu clan’s ceremonial cap was fashioned—Gaozu crafted a bamboo-skin cap at Xinfeng, one style called the *Weimao* cap. The scholars of Zou and Lu, the Ru and Mo, were gathered, and the teachings of the former sages were transmitted. The Son of Heaven’s banner was raised, the grand chariot mounted, the nine streamers unfurled, the great bells struck, the sounding drums beaten, the *Xianchi* performed, and the *Ganqi* dance enacted, as recorded in the *Rites of Zhou*.

The *Great Chariot* is the supreme chariot. When a king’s achievements are complete, he creates music, hence the striking of bells and beating of drums. *Xianchi* is the music of the Yellow Emperor. *Gan* refers to shields, and *qi* to axes—these are the implements held by dancers in spring and summer.

At this time, those who established martial rule were viewed with suspicion. *Suspicion* here means doubt. Within a single generation, civil and martial governance alternated in dominance, each employed as the times required. Yet in the present age, those who practice martial rule dismiss civil governance, while those who uphold civil governance dismiss martial rule. They mutually condemn one another, unaware of the demands of their era. This is like seeing only a corner of a room and remaining ignorant of the vastness of the eight directions. *A corner of a room* refers to a confined space, narrow and small; *the eight directions* signify the boundless expanse of the eight cardinal points. Thus, one who faces east cannot see the western wall, and one who looks south cannot perceive the north—only one who turns toward nothingness can comprehend all directions. *Turning toward nothingness* means perceiving the four quarters, hence the saying: "There is nothing it does not penetrate."

A state endures through virtue and power; when virtue and power are enacted, the people delight in their transformation, and so the state endures. A household perishes through the obstruction of principle. *Principle* is the Way. Yao ruled without a walled city of a hundred households, and Shun possessed not even land enough to plant an awl, yet they held all under Heaven. Yu had no following of ten men, and Tang no domain of seven *li*, yet they reigned over the feudal lords. King Wen dwelled between Qi and Zhou with a territory no larger than a hundred *li*, yet he rose to become the Son of Heaven—this was because he possessed the kingly Way. Yao, Shun, Yu, Tang, and King Wen all ruled all under Heaven. As Mencius said, "Those who practice virtue and benevolence become kings without waiting"—this is the same principle.

In their heyday, the might of Jie of Xia and Zhou of Yin extended wherever human footsteps reached, wherever boats and chariots traveled, all made into commanderies and counties. Yet they died at the hands of others and became laughingstocks of the world—this was because they bore the signs of ruin. As Mencius said, "They loathed death and delighted in unrighteousness; unrighteousness must lead to death," hence the saying: "They bore the signs of ruin."

Thus, the sage observes transformations to discern their omens. *Omens* signify fulfillment. When virtue waxes or wanes, the winds of change first appear. *Winds* refer to *qi*; *appear* means to manifest. Those of abundant virtue—such as King Wen—were foreseen by Boyi and the Grand Duke. Those of declining virtue—such as Jie—were first abandoned by the Grand Scribe Zhong Gu and Xiang Yi.

Therefore, those who attain the kingly Way, though small, will surely grow great—Tang and Wu are examples. Those who bear the signs of ruin, though established, will surely fall—Jie and Zhou are examples. When Xia was about to perish, the Grand Scribe Zhong Gu first fled to Shang; three years later, Jie was destroyed—Tang overthrew him. When Yin was about to collapse, the Grand Scribe Xiang Yi first submitted to King Wen; a year later, Zhou was annihilated—King Wu destroyed him. Thus, the sage perceives the traces of survival and ruin, the junctures of success and failure, not merely at the wilds of Mingtiao or on the day of Jiazi. Tang vanquished Jie and captured him at Mingtiao; King Wu punished Zhou and triumphed on the day of Jiazi.

Now, if the strong prevail by measuring land and counting multitudes, and the wealthy profit by weighing grain and gold, then every lord of a thousand chariots would become a hegemon or king, and every state of ten thousand chariots would face destruction. The traces of survival and ruin would be so easily discerned that even fools and simple women could discuss them. *Fools* here means dull-witted, lacking intelligence.

Zhao Xiangzi made Jinyang his bastion of hegemony, while Zhi Bo was captured with the lands of the Three Jin. *Zhi Bo* refers to Zhi Xian; *Xiangzi* is Wuxu. The Three Jin—Zhi, Han, and Wei—were united under Zhi Bo, who led the lords of Han and Wei to besiege Zhao Xiangzi at Jinyang. Zhao Xiangzi sent Zhang Mengtan to negotiate with Han and Wei, who then turned against Zhi Bo, crushing his army and taking his head to fashion a drinking vessel—hence the saying: "captured with the lands of the Three Jin." King Min of Qi perished with his great state, slain by Chunshen. Tian Dan achieved merit at Jimo. When Yan invaded Qi and conquered it, seizing seventy cities, only Jimo remained unconquered. Tian Dan, a market officer, led the people of Jimo to strike the Yan forces and defeated them—thus he was able to achieve merit.

Therefore, the fall of a state, though vast, is not to be relied upon—even the great may perish, as Zhi Bo did. The practice of the Way, though small, must not be taken lightly. Tang ruled with seventy *li*, and King Wen with a hundred *li*, yet both held all under Heaven—thus, though small, it must not be taken lightly.

From this, we see that survival lies in attaining the Way, not in greatness. A lord who attains the Way, though small, can do good and rule all under Heaven—hence it is said: "not in greatness." Ruin lies in losing the Way, not in smallness. A lord without the Way, though small, persists in evil without reform, and accumulation leads to ruin—hence it is said: "not in smallness."

The *Book of Songs* says:
*"Then gazing westward, he turned his regard,
This alone shall be our dwelling."*
This speaks of departing Yin and moving to Zhou. Zhou ruled from Chaoge in the east, while King Wen’s state lay in Qi and Zhou in the west. Heaven then turned its regard to the western lands, saying, "This alone shall be our dwelling"—hence the saying: "departing Yin and moving to Zhou."

Thus, the rulers of disordered states strive to expand their territories but neglect benevolence and righteousness; they seek to elevate their positions but disregard virtue and power. In doing so, they abandon what sustains them and create the conditions for their own ruin.

Jie was imprisoned at Jiaomen yet did not reproach his own conduct—he did not condemn the evil of his actions—but only regretted not killing Tang at the Summer Terrace. *Terrace* is sometimes written as *Palace*. Zhou was confined at Xuan Hall yet did not repent his faults—*repent* means to feel remorse—but only regretted not executing King Wen at Youli. *Regret* here means resentment. Youli is present-day Tangyin in Henan.

"Yǒu" is an ancient term for "prison warden." When these two rulers held overwhelming power and authority, had they cultivated the Dao of benevolence and righteousness, Tang and Wu would not have had the means to execute their punitive campaigns—how could any plot against them have succeeded? These two rulers refer to Jie and Zhou. While they reigned, their might and dominance blinded them to the wrongness of their own conduct. Had they but practiced the Dao of benevolence and righteousness, Tang and Wu would not have dared devise schemes to execute them.

Yet when they threw into chaos the brilliance of the Three Luminaries above and lost the hearts of the myriad people below—the Three Luminaries being the sun, moon, and stars—even without Tang and Wu, who could not have seized their thrones? This means that any capable person could have overthrown them; it need not have been Tang or Wu. Now, instead of examining their own conduct, they turned to guard against others. They failed to cultivate their own virtue and power, yet sought to defend against the world’s condemnation. The world does not have only one Tang or Wu—kill one, and another will surely follow.

Moreover, Tang and Wu, though small and weak, could attain kingship because they possessed the Dao. Jie and Zhou, though strong and dominant, were overthrown because they lacked the Dao. Now, instead of practicing what leads to kingship, they only compounded what leads to their own downfall—this is the path to ruin.

When King Wu conquered Yin, he wished to build a palace on the Mountain of the Five Phases. This Mountain of the Five Phases is present-day Mount Taihang, located north of Heyang County in Henan, at the Shangdang Pass. The Duke of Zhou said, "This cannot be done. The Mountain of the Five Phases is a place of solid barriers and perilous terrain. If our virtue can encompass it, the world will submit its tribute and service, though the journey be circuitous and difficult. *Circuitous* is sometimes written as *certain*. *Certain* means *inevitable*. But if we act with violence and disorder, the world will find it difficult to attack us." The Duke of Zhou meant that if they acted with violence and disorder, the world would come to punish them, and there would be no need to rely on the Mountain of the Five Phases to make their attackers’ task difficult. This is to say, they should rely on virtue, not on terrain. This is why the Zhou dynasty endured for thirty-six generations without being overthrown. The Duke of Zhou could truly be called one who "held fullness." *Fullness* means being full yet not overflowing. Hence the saying: "able to hold fullness."

Formerly, the *Book of Zhou* stated: "The words of superiors are put into practice by inferiors; the words of inferiors are put into practice by superiors. Approval and disapproval complement one another. The words of superiors are the constant; they are the constant of the ruler. The words of inferiors are the expedient; this is the art of survival and ruin. *Expedient* means *strategy*—weighing circumstances and acting without losing the Dao. Only the sage can master the expedient."

To speak and be invariably trustworthy, to set a time and invariably meet it—these are the highest conduct in the world. Yet when the upright man of She, whose father had stolen a sheep, bore witness against him—the upright man was a native of Ye County in Chu—Zigao, the Viscount of Ye, said to Confucius, "In my village there is an upright man: when his father stole a sheep, his son bore witness against him." Confucius replied, "The upright in my village differ from this. Fathers cover for their sons, and sons cover for their fathers—uprightness lies therein." *Stealing* refers to taking livestock that comes of its own accord. Weisheng made an appointment with a woman and died for it. Weisheng was a man of Lu who had arranged to meet a woman beneath a bridge; when the waters rose, he drowned. To be upright and testify against one’s father, to be trustworthy and drown for an appointment—though one may possess uprightness and trustworthiness, who could esteem such conduct?

To falsify orders in the Three Armies is a grave transgression. When Duke Mu of Qin raised troops to raid Zheng, he passed through Zhou on his eastward march. To attack a state with troops without sounding the drums—stealthily—is called *raiding*. Zhou was the royal capital. The *Gongyang Commentary* states: "The royal capital is Zhou west of the River," referring to present-day Henan County. The Zheng merchant Xian Gao was driving cattle westward to sell when he encountered the Qin army between Zhou and Zheng. He then falsified the orders of the Earl of Zheng, presenting twelve cattle to provision the Qin troops and hosting them as guests, thereby turning them back. *Falsifying* means claiming an order that was not given. *Provisioning* with wine and meat is called *xiang*; with cattle and sheep, *kao*—reviving what is withered. The Qin army said, "We have marched a thousand *li* to raid them, but the distant lord is prepared and our forces have no reinforcements. It would be better to return." They then withdrew their troops and departed, hence the saying "turned them back." Thus, he preserved the state of Zheng.

Therefore, in some matters, trustworthiness becomes transgression, and falsehood becomes merit. *Trustworthiness becoming transgression* refers to Weisheng; *falsehood becoming merit* refers to Xian Gao. What is meant by "acting contrary to ritual yet achieving great merit"? Formerly, when King Gong of Chu fought at Yinling—King Gong battled Duke Li of Jin at Yinling—Lü Qi shot King Gong in the eye and captured him. Because he later mended his ways, he was called *Gong* (Respectful). Pan Wang, Yang Youji, Huang Shuaiwei, and Gongsun Bing conspired to rescue him. These four were ministers of Chu. *Shuai* is read like *sheng* in *shengwei* (rope’s end); *wei* is read like *wen* in *wencao* (to wipe sincerely). King Gong, terrified, lost his composure; his dignity and bearing were not as usual, and he could not rise from his seat. Huang Shuaiwei lifted his foot and kicked the king’s body, whereupon King Gong awoke. Enraged by this breach of ritual, he roused himself and stood, and the four ministers carried him away. *Breach of ritual* refers to lifting one’s foot and kicking the ruler.

Formerly, Cangwu Rao took a wife of surpassing beauty and yielded her to his elder brother—this is what is called "loyal and loving yet impracticable." Cangwu Rao was a contemporary of Confucius. Because his wife was beautiful, he offered her to his elder brother. Though this was loving toward his brother, it violated the principle of honoring close kin and observing proper order, hence the saying "impracticable."

Thus, the sage, in judging the twists and turns of affairs, adapts to them with flexibility, bending and rising without fixed form. At times, he is lowly, weak, and pliant as rushes and leather—not from cowardice or submission. At others, he is firm, strong, and fiercely resolute, his aspirations soaring to the blue clouds—not from innate arrogance. This is to seize the moment and respond to change.

In the intercourse between ruler and minister, bowing the knee and lowering the body serve to express mutual respect and propriety. Yet when peril presses, one may raise a foot to trample the ruler’s person—none in the world would condemn this. Thus, where loyalty resides, ritual propriety cannot constrain it.

When a filial son serves his parents, he softens his countenance and humbles his posture, bearing their sash and adjusting their shoes—*yun* means to turn or adjust. But if they fall into the water, he seizes their hair to pull them out—*zheng* means to lift or rescue, for one rescues from drowning. He does not dare arrogance or disrespect; he acts to save their lives. Thus, when a father drowns, one seizes his hair; when praying, one names the ruler. Mencius said, "If one’s sister-in-law drowns and one does not rescue her, one is a jackal or wolf—how much more so for father or elder brother?" Hence, when drowning occurs, one rescues; when praying, one names the ruler. The Zhou people, in their reverence for the divine, avoided naming the ruler in prayers—yet circumstances leave no alternative. This is where expediency is applied.

Thus Confucius said, "One may study together, yet not be fit to follow the Way." *Shi* means to go; the Way is the virtuous path of benevolence and righteousness. "One may follow the Way, yet not be fit to stand." To stand is to establish virtue, merit, and teachings. "One may stand, yet not be fit to exercise expediency." Expediency is what only the sage perceives.

Thus, one who first resists and later conforms is said to understand expediency. *Wu* means to oppose or diverge; expediency adapts to circumstances, weighing light and heavy without fixed form, transforming the ugly into the good and aligning with what is fitting. Only the sage perceives this. One who conforms first and later errs is said not to understand expediency. Those who do not understand it turn good into ugliness.

Thus ritual is the flower of substance and the ornament of pretense. When pressed by sudden peril or dire straits, it has no use—ritual is of no avail. Therefore, the sage engages the world with formality but acts in accordance with what is fitting. He does not cling to a single path, rigid and unyielding. Thus he fails little and succeeds much; his commands are obeyed throughout the world, and none can condemn them.

To cling is to be bound. The *xingxing*—a beast of the northern lands, with a human face and animal body, yellow in color—knows what has passed but not what is to come. As the *Records of Ritual* says, "The *xingxing* can speak, yet remains a beast of the wild. Seeing people pass, it learns their names—this is knowing what has passed."

The *xingxing* also has a fondness for wine. People use wine to trap it, and once it drinks, it cannot stop—unaware of when it will become drunk, it is thus captured. Hence it is said to be unable to know what is to come.

The *ganhu*—the magpie—knows what is to come but not what has passed. When a person is about to encounter an omen of sorrow or joy, the *ganhu* cries out; this is knowing what is to come. It knows that years with frequent winds will lead it to build nests on the branches of trees, where people will steal its eggs. Hence it is said to be unable to know what has passed. *Gan* is read as in "dry" (*ganzao*); *hu* is read as in "retreat" (*gaotui*).

Such is the distinction between long and short foresight.

In ancient times, Chang Hong was the master of calculations in the Zhou court. Chang Hong was a minister of King Jing of Zhou. He was versed in the *shu*—the arts of the calendar. The qi of Heaven and Earth, the movements of the sun and moon, the changes of wind and rain, and the numbers of pitch-pipes and calendars—there was nothing he did not comprehend. Yet he could not foresee his own fate, and died by dismemberment. During the rebellion of Fan and Zhonghang clans in Jin, he had betrayed his lord. The Liu clan of Zhou had long been intermarried with the Fan clan of Jin, and Chang Hong served Duke Wen of Liu, so the people of Zhou aided the Fan clan. In the twenty-eighth year of King Jing, the people of Jin reproached Zhou, and Zhou executed Chang Hong to appease them. Thus it is said he could not foresee his own fate and died by dismemberment.

Su Qin was a commoner who traveled on foot. With a leather satchel and a humble canopy, he managed the affairs of rulers of ten thousand chariots and secured the compliance of the feudal lords. Yet he could not escape the disaster of dismemberment. Su Qin was a man of Luoyang. *Ying* refers to a leather satchel; *gai* refers to a walking canopy. Su Qin became chief minister of Zhao, which enfeoffed him as Lord Wu’an. Initially, he carried a satchel and a canopy, traveling to persuade the rulers of ten thousand chariots. He formed the Vertical Alliance of the eastern mountains, analyzing the advantages and disadvantages of the situation, and none could resist him. He made the feudal lords submit, and none dared refuse. Thus it is said he secured the compliance of the feudal lords but could not escape the disaster of dismemberment. This is discussed in the chapter on persuasive speech.

Here ends the nineteenth scroll of the *Huainan Honglie Jie*.

Here ends the twentieth scroll of the *Huainan Honglie Jie*, recorded by Minister of the Grand Commandant and Libationer Xu Shen.

Here begins a general discourse on instruction:

King Xu of Xu clothed himself in kindness and benevolence, conducting himself with humanity and justice. Thirty-two states on land came to pay court to him. Yet he perished, his state was destroyed, and his descendants were wiped out. In an age of decline and chaos, King Xu cultivated humanity and justice, yet made no military preparations. The King of Chu annihilated him, and thus he perished along with his state. As the *Seven Admonitions* states: "King Wen of Jing erred, and Xu perished"—this is the case.

Minister Zhong assisted and guided King Goujian of Yue, aiding him in avenging grievances and wiping away shame. He captured the person of Fuchai, expanding territory by thousands of *li*. Yet in the end, he was forced to take his own life with the *shulou* sword. Goujian, deploying his stratagems, exacted vengeance upon King Fuchai of Wu, gaining a thousand *li* of land. Yet in the end, the King of Yue grew suspicious of him and presented him with the *shulou* to die. The *shulou* is a sharp sword. Another account says: a long sword with a deer-horn-shaped pommel, its tip dragging on the ground, trailing as one walks.

These men all grasped the mechanisms of order and chaos—*ji* meaning the essential point—yet did not know the means to preserve their nature. Thus, Chang Hong understood the Way of Heaven but not human affairs; Su Qin knew stratagems but not fortune and misfortune; King Xu of Xu knew humanity and justice but not timing; Minister Zhong knew loyalty but not planning. They did not know how to plan for themselves.

The sage is not thus. He assesses the age and acts accordingly, weighing matters and devising plans. Thus, he can extend his influence across the world without constraint, and apply it in the smallest matters without obstruction. *Not constrained* means that in great matters, he can act greatly. Eight *chi* make a *xun*; twice a *xun* makes a *chang*. In small matters, he can act small, without causing urgency or blockage.

If the world falls into desolation and chaos, ritual and justice are severed, the web of governance collapses, the strong oppress the weak, force is used to seize and plunder, minister and lord are indistinguishable, noble and base lack order, armor breeds wax-moths and lice—*cheng* meaning to ride upon, *rang* meaning to level—*breeding wax-moths and lice* means they never leave the body. Swallows and sparrows nest in tents and curtains—*wo* meaning a tent, *chu* meaning to dwell like a bird in its nest. Yet if warfare does not cease, and only then does one begin to adopt the demeanor of reverent restraint—*shuyu* describing a respectful and cautious appearance—and practice the rites of humility and frugality, one will surely be suppressed and unable to rise.

If the world is at peace, governance and education are harmonious, the hundred clans are respectful and harmonious, superiors and inferiors are affectionate toward one another, and only then does one begin to display arrogance and self-importance—*jin* meaning self-aggrandizement—and exert one’s strength and courage, one will surely not escape the laws of the authorities.

Thus, the sage is capable of both yin and yang, both weakness and strength. He moves or remains still according to the times, establishes merit based on available resources, perceives the return of things when they move, and discerns change when matters first sprout. When transformation occurs, he provides its image; when the course shifts, he responds accordingly. Thus, he acts throughout his life without ever encountering difficulty.

Therefore, there are matters that can be done but cannot be spoken of, matters that can be spoken of but cannot be done, matters that are easy to undertake but difficult to complete, and matters that are difficult to complete but easy to ruin.

What can be done but cannot be spoken of is the choice between advancing and retreating. What can be spoken of but cannot be done is deceit and falsehood. What is easy to undertake but difficult to complete is affairs. What is difficult to complete but easy to ruin is reputation. These four strategies are what the sage alone perceives and pays heed to.

To dig an inch to extend a foot—the sage does this. An inch is small, a foot is large. To bend slightly to achieve great straightness—the noble person practices this. *Bent* means crooked; *straight* means aligning with the Way.

The Duke of Zhou bore the burden of killing his younger brother—he executed Guan and Cai. Duke Huan bore the reputation of contending for the state—he entered first from Ju and killed Prince Jiu. Yet the Duke of Zhou mended the breach with righteousness, aiding King Cheng to bring about great peace, returning governance after seven years and facing north as a minister. Thus it is said he mended the breach with righteousness. Duke Huan obliterated disgrace with merit, establishing the achievement of uniting the feudal lords nine times and correcting the world, erasing the evil of contending for the state. Both were deemed worthy.

If one were to obscure a person’s great virtues because of minor faults, then the world would have no sage-kings or worthy ministers. Thus, a blemish in the eye does not impair vision—it cannot be burned away. *Blemish* means a growth; *burn* means to cauterize. An ailment in the throat does not obstruct breathing—it cannot be chiseled away. *Chisel* means to bore through. The burial mounds along the Yellow River are innumerable, yet the land remains easy to cultivate.
